Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: New Political Parties, Societal Linkages and Developing Stable Ties with Voters

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

This project offers a new explanation of how voters become partisans. The PI examines the different trajectories of new parties and asks why some are able to take root in society, establish stable ties with voters quickly, and successfully compete in elections over time, while others fail to do so. Most prior research focuses on parties' direct appeals to voters. This research also explains success in terms of different types of direct appeals to groups that organize around social cleavages. Stable ties between a party and societal organizations may also attach organization members to that party and socialize them into identifying with it. The PI argues that organizational linkages can yield more stable voter-party ties and support bases. The PI test his argument using a multi-method strategy. This research contributes to our understanding of how traditionally marginalized groups are incorporated into the electoral arena through parties.

Technical Summary

This project examines the different trajectories of new parties and asks why some are able to take root in society, establish stable ties with voters quickly, and successfully compete in elections over time, while others fail to do so. Most prior research focuses on parties' direct appeals to voters. This research also explains success in terms of different types of direct appeals to groups that organize around social cleavages. Stable ties between a party and societal organizations may also attach organization members to that party and socialize them into identifying with it. The PI argues that organizational linkages can yield more stable voter-party ties and support bases. The PI test his argument using a multi-method strategy, integrating conjoint experiments on the microfoundations of party support, comparative case studies of new parties in Bolivia, Ecuador, and Mexico, statistical analysis of survey data; and ecological inference leveraging a new data set. This project advances our understanding of new parties and contributes to efforts to promote sustained representation that is accountable to broad population segments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In democracies, parties play a central role in representation, linking society and the state. Yet many new democracies have been characterized by unstable parties, and thus have faced crises of representation. This has been particularly visible in Latin America: after the neoliberal reforms in the 80s/90s, many traditional parties were discredited, lost electoral support, and virtually disappeared. The new parties that have emerged since then vary greatly in terms of the stability of their ties with voters and of their support bases.

This project examines the different trajectories of new parties and asks why some are able to take root in society, establish stable ties with voters quickly, and successfully compete in elections over time, while others fail to do so. In some countries, such as Bolivia, new mass parties with enduring ties to voters have emerged. In other countries, such as Ecuador, similar new parties failed to establish stable ties to voters. Last, in some countries, such as Mexico, new parties had some success in establishing enduring ties with voters but only for a small part of the electorate.

These outcomes are explored by comparing the types of linkages new parties forge through direct appeals to voters (class, ethnic, clientelistic appeals) versus through organizationally mediated strategies, i.e. appeals that build ties to voters through societal organizations. While most prior research has focused on parties’ direct appeals to voters and has explained success in securing electoral support in terms of different types of direct appeals (e.g., ethnic vs. clientelistic), groups that organize around social cleavages-such as indigenous movements, peasant unions, informal sector unions, and labor unions-can provide an alternate source of support. Stable ties between a party and societal organizations, which serve as highly relevant, immediate reference groups to their members, may attach organization members to that party and socialize them into identifying with it. Thereby, organizational linkages can yield more stable voter-party ties and support bases.

The analysis of the data reveals interesting patterns for vote choice and partisan attachments. More specifically, the results of the poster experiments suggest that organizationally mediated appeals are very effective in obtaining electoral support, especially when voters face a new party. In fact, the results show that organizational endorsements can even overcome other cross-cutting divides. For example, voters follow organizational endorsements even for candidates whose policy preferences are not congruent with their own and when facing candidates that are no co-ethnic with them.

This project offers a new explanation of how voters become partisans. While scholars have presented convincing arguments for the decline in identification with traditional parties (Lupu 2014; Roberts 2014; Seawright 2012), little is known about how voters actually come to identify with new parties and the emergence of such parties, especially in less institutionalized democracies. Also, this project adds to the debate about the different functions served by parties and the changing relationship between parties, civil society, and voters (Chandra 2004; Kitschelt 2000; Levitsky 2003; Stokes et al. 2013). Last, it provides important insights into the politicization of social structures and the representation of ethnicity and class.

Beyond the specific cases, the project elucidates how parties represent and mediate societal interests. This is not only of theoretical importance but also highly relevant to our broader understanding of state-society relations. Understanding why only some parties are successful in ‘taking root in society’ has far reaching implications for representation and accountability, in particular for new democracies. Second, given how pervasive new parties are in new and well-established democracies, this project advances our understanding of new parties and contributes to efforts to promote the transition from weak ephemeral parties to strong, established parties capable of sustained representation and accountable to broad population segments. Last, juxtaposing different categories of marginality, it provides important insights into the role of ethnicity, class, and gender in developing countries and elucidates the different ways in which traditionally marginalizedgroups such as indigenous populations or informal workers are incorporated into the electoral arena through parties.
